utterance.speaker: Emma
utterance.content: Hey.

utterance.speaker: Tyson Ritter
utterance.content: You got this whole thing wrong, Em. It’s the rock star that’s supposed to be late, not the rock star photographer.

utterance.speaker: Emma
utterance.content: Sorry. Morning sickness. Touch the belly.

utterance.speaker: Tyson
utterance.content: It’s the first time I’ve been asked to do that.

utterance.speaker: Emma
utterance.content: Come on. It’s good luck.

utterance.speaker: Tyson
utterance.content: Mmm. Ooh

utterance.speaker: Emma
utterance.content: Get the keynotes behind the drop. So, what do you think?

utterance.speaker: Tyson
utterance.content: Uh, I think people aren’t going to get it.

utterance.speaker: Emma
utterance.content: Come on. All-American Rejects. Juxtaposing a classic image of Americana with modern pop culture. You.

utterance.speaker: Tyson
utterance.content: Oh, yeah. Everyone loves a good juxtaposition. My fans were born in the 90s.

utterance.speaker: Emma
utterance.content: You know what? You do this picture, you’ll gain forty years of fans.

utterance.speaker: Tyson
utterance.content: Yeah?

utterance.speaker: Emma
utterance.content: Yeah.

utterance.speaker: Tyson
utterance.content: Love the Rockwell thing.

utterance.speaker: Emma
utterance.content: I thought so. Okay. Kill the house lights. Let’s go. Hang on. Hey. Who’s in charge of the backdrop? Naomi!

utterance.speaker: Naomi
utterance.content: Yeah?

utterance.speaker: Tyson
utterance.content: What’s wrong with it?

utterance.speaker: Emma
utterance.content: Uh, well the words are completely jumbled. What? You can read that?

utterance.speaker: Tyson
utterance.content: Of course. You okay?

utterance.speaker: Emma
utterance.content: No. Oh, God. I could be having a… a… What’s the mnemonic? Uh… F. F is for face. Is my smile crooked?

utterance.speaker: Tyson
utterance.content: What are you doing?

utterance.speaker: Emma
utterance.content: A. A is for arms. Arms.

utterance.speaker: Tyson
utterance.content: You should really sit down. Can somebody get her some water.

utterance.speaker: Emma
utterance.content: S. S is speech. I’m slurring. I’m slurring? Huh. Oh! Oh. F-A-S-T. T is time. Hurry, somebody, uh. Call 911. Tell them I’m having a stroke.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Hi. I’m Dr. House. My boss says you’re important.

utterance.speaker: Emma
utterance.content: Oh.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Personally I don’t get what’s so hard about making Scarlett Johansson look pretty. Arms out in front of you. With your palms up, like you’re holding a pizza. Close your eyes.

utterance.speaker: Emma
utterance.content: It’s so easy, you should consider a career change. Probably make a lot more money.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Dr. Mackman tell you the clot was clear?

utterance.speaker: Emma
utterance.content: Yes.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: And he said you and the fetus are fine.

utterance.speaker: Emma
utterance.content: Yeah.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: He didn’t mention your pronator drift.

utterance.speaker: Emma
utterance.content: What’s that mean?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It means Mackman is an idiot. May I?

utterance.speaker: Emma
utterance.content: Yeah.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: So. You take thousands of photos of someone but only one has to look good. Kind of the opposite of my business.

utterance.speaker: Emma
utterance.content: It’s not about looking good. People are always hiding things. I just keep shooting until I can see what’s really inside them. My eyes okay?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Eyes are gorgeous. Vessels don’t look so hot. Micro-aneurysms predict further strokes.

utterance.speaker: Emma
utterance.content: This is going to happen again?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Unless I can figure out the underlying cause. Puff up your cheeks. You should be able to keep the air in. It means there’s weakness around the mouth. So, where’d you learn to self-diagnose a stroke?

utterance.speaker: Emma
utterance.content: Oh, my uh… baby’s biological father is a neurologist. He once told me the FAST mnemonic could save my life one day so –

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Interesting pet name. Most people go with “husband” or “pookie.”

utterance.speaker: Emma
utterance.content: He’s gay. Just a sperm donor. So when you –

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You turned him for a night? Just straight for one date?

utterance.speaker: Emma
utterance.content: Okay. He took a magazine and a cup into my bathroom.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: A man after my own heart. Different magazine, obviously. I’m rescinding Mackman’s discharge order. My lackeys will be in to do some more tests, take some more blood and empty your catheter bag. Not a moment you’ll want to cherish.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: This is… definitely different.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: It looks almost like –

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: He’s caring.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Find anything else in the patient’s folder? Like a diagnosis?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Urinalysis revealed excessive protein and red blood cells. Chem panel showed a creatinine level over 2.5.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: So first she strokes, now her kidneys are shutting down. Why?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Ultrasound showed no tumors or stones, no signs of fetal distress, no urinary tract obstructions.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: BP is fine. No preeclampsia.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Any of you guys ever been to the Galapagos?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Was our patient there? Dengue fever, avian pox. Even West Nile.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No. I’m looking for a vacation spot.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: That mean we get vacation?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: How would that differ from your current status?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: You’re going to do what? Relax?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Visiting family. My uncle’s a giant turtle.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: What if the kidney failure came first? Kidneys could have caused the stroke, not the other way around.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Kidneys don’t often get stuck in the brain.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: I’m saying it threw a clot. Early symptoms of kidney failure are nausea, vomiting, swelling. She could have mistaken it for morning sickness.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Heart’s way more likely to throw a clot than the kidney.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Echo’s normal. The history indicates no sign of cardiac problems.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No, but if one were to read the history closely, one would have noticed that she had six cases of strep.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: In her throat. That’s the one about 10 inches above the heart.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Let me rephrase. Six cases of untreated strep.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: She was prescribed antibiotics.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No one takes them all. They stop when they start feeling better. All strep is untreated strep. What happens when strep goes untreated?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: It leads to rheumatic fever.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Which leads to, Cameron?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Mitral valve stenosis.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Which is a thickening in the valve of the…kidney? No. The kidney doesn’t have a mitral valve.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: We’ll go look at the heart.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It’ll be easy to find. It’s the big, red pumping thing about ten inches below her throat.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: That was weird.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: He was the way he always is.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Which is weird. Stay still, Emma.

utterance.speaker: Emma
utterance.content: Sorry.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: No problem. He caught us with your hand up my shirt. He’s gotta have a reaction to that. You think that’s what the vacation is?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Yes. The pain of losing you is obviously forcing him away. Coronal slice appears normal.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: There’s no way House just lets this slide. He’s gotta be planning something.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Maybe he just doesn’t give a crap. Sagittal slice is clean.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: You think he just stumbled into that closet? He knew we were there. And he wanted us to know that he knew.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Or, you wanted him to know. Now he does and you’re annoyed because he doesn’t care. Right there. Transaxial slice. Calcified mitral valve.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Barely. That’s not big enough to throw a clot.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Obviously it is because it did. House was right.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: The valve in your heart is narrowed. It caused the clot which led to your stroke and the reduced circulation caused the problems with your kidneys.

utterance.speaker: Emma
utterance.content: And this’ll fix it?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: The balloon will force the valve back open and you’ll be fine.

utterance.speaker: Emma
utterance.content: Can I do this without a sedative.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: It’s really very mild. There really is no risk to the fetus.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: We’ll monitor the baby’s heart rate separately. We won’t allow it to decrease anywhere near dangerous levels. {She turns on second monitor which shows a heart rate of 208.]

utterance.speaker: Emma
utterance.content: Thank you.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: You’re both going to be fine. Go ahead, Dr. Cameron.

utterance.speaker: Emma
utterance.content: Listen to that heartbeat… Sounds so –

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Start threading the catheter.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I don’t want a layover in Frankfurt, Taipei, Singapore or London, Ontario. That’s why I asked for a direct flight to Phnom Penh. How hard is it to not land? Does it matter what I answer? Well then, fine, I’d be delighted to hold. What’s new?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Can you tell Cuddy to stop interfering?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It’s her job. What’s new?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: The good news is Emma’s heart is fixed. The bad news is it’s not her underlying problem. Her kidneys are still failing.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: You’re vacationing in Cambodia? You’re going to unwind in the killing fields?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Nope. Gonna catch me a fish this big. Mekong giant catfish weighs over 600 pounds.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Aren’t those catfish critically endangered?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: That’s why it’s my last chance to catch one. If the mitral valve had been fixed, the kidneys should be getting better which leads us to the conclusion that you screwed up the procedure.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Or you screwed up the diagnosis. Mitral valve thickening was so insignificant it probably wasn’t the cause of the kidneys or the stroke. Probably never would have been a problem.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: She needs dialysis. And we need a new theory.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: There are only a few possibilities. Patient’s pregnant. It could be preeclampsia. We eliminated it before because –

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Check for proteinuria and low platelets. What else?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Hypoperfusion. The fetus is basically a parasite, stealing nutrients, minerals, blood.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Put her on telemetry.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Or the pregnancy’s irrelevant. Could be infection, sepsis, HUS/TTP –

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: A cholesterol embolism is just as likely. Tiny particles of cholesterol rain down, clog up the small vessels in the kidneys.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Get a smear and ultrasound her vessels for plaque.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: That’s it, has to be one of those five.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You know what would be even better? If we could narrow it all the way down to one.

utterance.speaker: Phone
utterance.content: Thank you for holding. We are experiencing extremely high call volume. Thank you for your patience.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: She’s 0 for 5.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Either the differential was wrong or she’s faking it.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Kidney failure has to be precipitated by –

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: By one of the five we’ve already ruled out.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: The body only has so many ways of screwing with the kidneys. The labs must be wrong.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: We did the labs. No one else had access.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: That’s not quite true.

utterance.speaker: Emma
utterance.content: You put all your patients through this many tests or just the important ones?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: We wanted to explore all the possibilities.

utterance.speaker: Emma
utterance.content: And?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: We’ve eliminated all the possibilities.

utterance.speaker: Emma
utterance.content: You’re telling me I’m dying and you have no idea why?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Your body is functioning properly.

utterance.speaker: Emma
utterance.content: So why are my kidneys failing?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: The other body isn’t. There’s something wrong with the fetus.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Welcome to the world of maternal mirror syndrome. Mom’s body is like an intricate German metro system. All the trains run on time. When she gets pregnant, it’s like a new station opening in Dusseldorf. A bunch of rookies running things, bound to be mistakes. Kids play on the tracks, get electrocuted. Before you know it, trains are backed up all the way to Berlin and you’ve got a bunch of angry Germans with nowhere to go. And we all know that ain’t good for the Jews.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Who are the Jews in this metaphor?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: A few things can happen to a fetus in distress. It can become a miscarriage, stillbirth, very sick baby or, on rare occasion, a time bomb that kills mom while it’s dying. The good news is, we fix the fetus, mom gets better. It’s the diagnostic equivalent of a two-for-one sale.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: I’ve read the outcome of mirror syndrome is almost always unfavorable.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Unfavorable. Is that doctor speak for “dead baby?” You think she’ll be less upset if you phrase it nicely?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: We can tell her the truth – that she’ll be fine as soon as we diagnose a person who weighs about one pound. Can’t touch it, can’t ask where it hurts, can’t see it.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: If only there existed giant machines that could look through human skin. Mirror syndrome has a limited number of known causes.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Tacharrythmia, fetal anemia, placental chorioangioma –

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: All of which are fixable. Which would be un-unfavorable, right?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Could also be trisomy 13, Epstein’s anomaly, an aneurysm of Galen’s vein –

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: And Dr. Storm Cloud rained all over the differential and killed the beautiful little baby. Heart’s easiest to see, easiest to fix, so let’s start there. When you did Mom’s MRI did you get a look at the fetus’ heart?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: It was in the range but blurry. The fetus was moving all over the place.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: So we need another scan.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Yeah. We’ll just ask the fetus to lie very, very still.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No need. I’m going to paralyze it.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: You want to paralyze Emma Sloan’s baby?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Let me guess. Cameron.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Cameron and Chase both had their concerns.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No, Cameron had concerns. Chase just agreed with her because he didn’t want to lose his all-access pass to her love rug.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: They’re sleeping together?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: If by “sleeping together” you mean having sex in the janitor’s closet.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Here?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No, the janitor’s closet at the local high school. Go, Tigercats. Do you have one of those camera-phones? Because I have a MySpace account.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: I will deal with them after I deal with you.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Oh, come on. Let’s gossip some more. I’m sure she’s into bondage.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Paralyzing a one-pound baby risks damaging –

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Not paralyzing the thing risks not getting a clean MRI of its heart. Which we need to save its life which we need to do to save Emma’s life.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: You’re gonna need to get her consent.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: That shouldn’t be too hard. Sign here or you and your baby both die.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: I’m going with you.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Oh, good.

utterance.speaker: Emma
utterance.content: You said sedation was risky. This sounds insane.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: The injection goes into the umbilical cord.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: The baby won’t feel a thing.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Fetus! I’m lowering expectations. It works here and on dates. The benefits outweigh the risks and the paralytic will wear off in an hour. Okay?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: It must be easier to hear that you might die than your baby might die. But if there’s anyone I would trust to save my baby, it would be Dr. House.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Fetus. Hold this.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Dr. Cameron, the MRI results back?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: The fetus’ heart is structurally sound. The problem’s with the bladder. It’s four times normal size.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Let me see.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: The bladder’s so engorged it’s taking up the whole torso, squeezing all the other organs. There’s no room for the lungs to develop.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: The baby has a lower urinary tract obstruction. We can fix that by inserting a shunt. I’ll give Emma the news.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Are you… taking over the case?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: House won’t care. He has his diagnosis. Dr. Cameron. Dating Chase… can only end in one of two ways.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: House told you?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: You get married and live happily ever after or somebody gets hurt and you two can’t work together and I have to fire somebody.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: I would hate to see my personal life become such a burden to you.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: I’m telling you this for your own good.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Well I assume you’re going to have this same conversation with Chase for his own good.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Chase isn’t the one who’s gonna get hurt here.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: There’s only room for one. Though I could scooch over.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: My social life is my social life.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Couldn’t agree more. What goes on in the privacy of a janitor’s closet is nobody’s business except –

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: She told me to end it. Is that what you want?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I was actually hoping she’d fire one of you.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: What are you doing?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Trying to avoid altitude sickness. Couldn’t score a direct flight to Cambodia so I decided to scale Argentina’s infamous Mount Aconcagua

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Perfect, except for the fact that you can’t walk.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: There’s a tribe of Macovi Indians who actually carry the elders up –

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: You’re insane.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I’m an insane genius. Set the chamber to low pressure instead of high. Thinner air builds up extra red blood cells. Creates new capillaries. Few more days in here and I can save myself six weeks in base camp. Where’s my MRI?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: There’s a blockage in the urinary tract. Simple terms, your baby can’t pee. His bladder is swollen and it’s crushing his lungs.

utterance.speaker: Emma
utterance.content: Well, can you fix it?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: We can insert a small tube in the baby’s bladder that makes the bladder come out straight through his belly for the duration of the pregnancy. The bladder decompresses and the lungs will be able to develop normally. When the baby gets better, you should get better.

utterance.speaker: Emma
utterance.content: Wow.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: First we just have to do a test to determine whether the baby’s kidneys are functioning properly.

utterance.speaker: Emma
utterance.content: And what if they’re not?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: If they’re already too damaged, then there’s really nothing we can do. If this doesn’t work out, you can always try again.

utterance.speaker: Emma
utterance.content: Wow. I miscarried twice when I was married. After the divorce, I tried in vitro like four times before this. I’m 42. Maybe it's, uh, just not meant to be.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: What are you doing?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Well, you’re trying to be me so I thought I’d try to be you.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: You don’t have the cleavage for it.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: But I have a much tighter ass. You think every day should be naked Thursday or is that an oxymoron? Let me see the results of the bladder tap.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: They aren’t back yet.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: They’re gonna to be inconclusive.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: You think my diagnosis is wrong?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Fetus doesn’t pee, amniotic fluid should be low. Mom’s level is fine.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Doesn’t mean I’m wrong. Could just mean we caught the obstruction early.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Either way, your test will be inconclusive. The urine you collected has been sitting in that fetus’ bladder for weeks. And, as my pappy always said, “stale pee is useless pee.”

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Fine, then I’ll do another tap.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Just as useless. Old urine drops down from the kidney right after the first tap ‘cause it’s all backed up. Bladder tap number three will give you the freshest pee and it’s when you’ll find out if this fetus has even a fighting chance.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Thank you. I’ll run two more taps.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Since when does the Dean of Medicine run bladder taps?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: She’s an important patient.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Because she takes pictures? Or because she’s you? Woman in her forties. Single. Using a turkey baster as a last gasp of motherhood. And you want to make sure she succeeds, so you’ll still have hope. Can’t be a good doctor if you’re not objective.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: It’s your file.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I don’t want it.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Then why did you just say all that stuff?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: To humiliate you.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: You’re taking the case back.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I don’t want it. Your diagnosis is right. I wanna go on vacation.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: You can go on vacation after you’ve cured her.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Good news. Fetus’ urine had appropriate levels of protein and electrolytes so its kidneys aren’t damaged.

utterance.speaker: Emma
utterance.content: Oh. Wow.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: We’re going to put the shunt in. Your baby’s lungs should have more room to grow and your symptoms should go away.

utterance.speaker: Emma
utterance.content: But he’ll still need surgery? After he’s born?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: That’s when we’ll remove the blockage in the ureter. You’ll be the only mother on the planet who appreciates the value of a wet diaper.

utterance.speaker: Emma
utterance.content: Hey, could you hand me that? I’m keeping a visual memory book of this entire, surreal process and this is the best part of the story so far.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Yeah. Sure.

utterance.speaker: Emma
utterance.content: Thanks.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: When did you take this?

utterance.speaker: Emma
utterance.content: Oh. She did the second bladder tap. You should keep it.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Oh, I see her all day at work. I don’t need it.

utterance.speaker: Emma
utterance.content: Maybe you want to see her after work. I’m right, right? I saw the way you look at her.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Thanks.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Shunt is in the right position. The bladder’s starting to decompress.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: No infection. Did House say anything else? About us?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: I thought you didn’t care about his reaction. Trying to make him jealous?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: I like my job.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: He can’t fire you just because we’re together.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: We’re not together. And House can do whatever he wants.

utterance.speaker: Emma
utterance.content: How’s my baby?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Doing just fine, Emma. So are you.

utterance.speaker: Emma
utterance.content: My stomach is killing me.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: That’s not her stomach.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Can you open your eyes, Emma? I just need to take a look.

utterance.speaker: Emma
utterance.content: What is it.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Emma’s jaundiced. Her liver’s shutting down.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Figures. Just booked my trip to Johnston Straight.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: I thought you were climbing Mount – whatever. In Argentina.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Apparently I’d have to live with the Macovi Indians for twenty years before they’d consider me an elder. I decided to go kayaking with orca instead. No legs required.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Can’t leave yet. Liver failure puts her case back in the unsolved pile.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Increased AST, ALT and her bilirubin’s off the charts.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Even fetuses lie. We diagnosed a lower urinary tract obstruction because we saw one. What if that’s not the whole story. What if the little bugger is hiding something? Real reason for the mirror syndrome. Have we looked under its bed? Have we checked its diary?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: It’s not GU. Could be the heart. Hypoplastic left heart syndrome.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: There were no structural problems.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: The lungs –

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: We won’t be able to get a good look until they develop. It’ll be weeks

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: She’s not going to last weeks.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: What do you want to do?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Maternal Mirror Syndrome has one surefire cure. Deliver the fetus.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: It’s not viable at twenty-one weeks. You’ll kill the baby.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Fetus.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Do semantics make you feel better? Pretend it’s not a person?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Can it play catch? Can it eat? Can it take pretty pictures? Who wants to tell her?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: The swollen bladder was not the only problem. We can’t leave it inside you. We have to terminate.

utterance.speaker: Emma
utterance.content: Well, can’t you deliver him? Put him on a respiratory machine until you figure out what’s wrong.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: We can. And it won’t matter. The fetus is still at least two weeks away from being viable.

utterance.speaker: Emma
utterance.content: Oh, well. I’ll suffer through this for at least two more weeks, then.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You’re on dialysis for your kidneys. Your kidneys can wait. They don’t make dialysis for your liver. You’re not going to make it two more days.

utterance.speaker: Emma
utterance.content: I’m not gonna let you kill my baby.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It’s killing you.

utterance.speaker: Emma
utterance.content: I’m not having an abortion.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It’s not a baby. It’s a…tumor. I understand dying for a cause, sacrificing your life so your child might live. But that’s not the choice here. Either it dies or you both die.

utterance.speaker: Emma
utterance.content: Or you fix him and we both live.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I can’t fix it. I’m scheduling a D and C.

utterance.speaker: Emma
utterance.content: I won’t consent. So I guess you have two days to figure it out.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Her kidneys are almost irreparable. She’s developed severe DIC. You have to force her to terminate.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Did you give corticosteroids to speed the baby’s lung development?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No! I dropped an anvil on its chest to prevent lung development. I’m trying to extinguish the human race one fetus at a time.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Give the lungs more time to expand so you can see inside them, see if they’re the problem.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: My real patient is dying. Very quickly. Like I wouldn’t advise her to buy any green bananas. The fetus is nothing more than a parasite at this point. Removing it is an instant cure.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: You’re not going to get Emma to see it that way. She’s probably already named the baby. Read him books, had conversations with him.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: See, you get it. She’ll listen to you.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: No.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You let this woman refuse to terminate, you’re helping her commit suicide. As her doctor, my recommendation is against suicide.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: If the baby had a doctor, I think she would recommend exhausting all possibilities before taking its life.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Then she’d be an idiot.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Too bad she’s your boss.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: What if our original assumption is wrong.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It isn’t.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: If we assume she doesn’t have mirror syndrome then terminating her pregnancy isn’t going to help her liver at all.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: We eliminated all other possibilities.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: The fetus is hydropic and in distress. Emma’s kidneys and liver are failing. The diagnosis is solid.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Wow. If the ass kisser won’t agree with you, you must be even wronger than I thought.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Fine. Let’s assume she had mirror syndrome but we fixed it when we fixed the baby’s bladder. That means that her failing liver would be completely unrelated. If it is, we can fix it. And we don’t have to terminate.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: So her theory is that our patient’s liver problems were just a giant coincidence.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: It’s not a surprising coincidence. Pregnant women can develop liver problems. If this is the case, we can actually do something here. Don’t you guys think that’s worth exploring.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Acute fatty liver of pregnancy would have the same symptoms.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Thank you.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Brown-noser.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Viral hepatitis. HELLP syndrome.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Oh look. Sticking up for your girlfriend. Who says chivalry’s dead?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: He’s not joking?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Be patient. She’s going through all of us. She’ll get that jungle fever eventually.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: I’m not going through anyone.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You love him?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: This can probably wait until after we biopsy Emma’s liver, right?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: We can’t. Her platelets are too low. Once we pierce her liver, it will be next to impossible to stop the bleeding.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Come in from above. Instead of going straight in through her abdomen, go in through the veins in her neck. Transjugular hepatic biopsy. If the liver starts to bleed, it will bleed right back into her own veins. Why don’t you start your vacation now?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Threading the guidewire through the right internal jugular vein.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: So, the sleep lab. You and Cameron not sleeping. How serious is it?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: It’s nothing. She’s only doing it to make House jealous.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Then why are you doing it?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Are you kidding?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: You’re approaching the inferior vena cava. Slow down. Better not hurt her.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: She already has a big brother.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: She does?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: You obviously care very deeply about her.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: I’m not protecting her. I’m protecting myself. A heartbroken, lovesick Cameron would be even more unbearable than she is now. You’re through the hepatic vein.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Firing the needle.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Heart rate and BP spiking. Get that out of her.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Fetus’ heart rate just dropped to 50. We’ve got contractions.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Pre-term labor. Start a terbutaline drip.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: We were able to control the pre-term labor with tocolytics. The contractions have subsided, for now.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: And the biopsy was negative. This is definitely mirror syndrome. Her baby’s doing this to her.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: We’re out of options.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Did the biopsy cause the pre-term labor or did it happen on its own?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: It doesn’t make a difference.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Pre-term labor can be a new symptom. New information gives us new theories. Isn’t that how it works?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Not in this case. Her body’s trying to do what you refuse to – get the baby out and save itself.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: The patient’s transaminases are ten times normal. Her liver’s on the verge of shutting down completely.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: A torch test could –

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: We don’t have time for more tests. We have to terminate or she’ll die.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Then let’s work faster.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Medicine doesn’t work faster just because you hope real hard.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: But it could help to see what the baby’s been hiding. The only organ we haven’t been able to look inside is its lungs. The problem must be in there.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: We haven’t been able to see inside because they’re underdeveloped. We’ve already got her on corticosteroids but it’ll take weeks for them –

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Then let’s drown them in corticosteroids. Multiple courses. Speed up their development.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Giving the baby more than one course will suppress adrenal gland function.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Have long-term adverse effects on fetal organ development.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Worse than death?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Emma’s already on tocolytics. The combination could put her into pulmonary edema. You’ll just kill her faster.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: It’s the only chance we have to see inside those lungs. We’re just going to have to make the baby better faster than we make Emma worse. Come on. This is the kind of thing House does every day.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: House thought we should terminate six hours ago.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: I’ll do it myself.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Anybody going to stop her?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Stopping the madness is her job.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Somebody’s got to be Cuddy’s Cuddy.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Nurse!

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Pulmonary edema?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Who tattled? Doesn’t matter.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: There’s a reason we don’t give multiple courses of corticosteroids.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Gee, thanks.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: It’s time to terminate.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: That’s not what she wants.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Look at her. She didn’t want to be an incubator for a dead baby, but that’s what you’ve done.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Either get me a laryngoscope or get out.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: You were right. You were all right. Now the mom’s lungs are shutting down. She’s dying faster than the baby’s lungs are developing. I had to stop the corticosteroids.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Have you spoken to the family?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: The only family she’s got is that baby.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Well, he’s biased.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: What do you think House would do?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: House wants to terminate.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: I know. I mean if he didn’t. If he shared my position. What do you think he would do?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: He wouldn’t share your pain. He’d be objective.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Right. He would prioritize his problems.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: He’d terminate.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: He wouldn’t be afraid of screwing with her lungs if there was a bigger issue.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: There is no bigger issue. She needs her lungs.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Not right now. She’s already on a respirator. The machine is breathing for her. I can do whatever I want to her lungs. If you’re playing catch in the living room and you break your mother’s vase you might as well keep playing catch. The vase is already broken.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Yeah, except that room can’t breathe without that vase.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: I’m putting her back on corticosteroids.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: It worked.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: What worked?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: I got the baby’s lungs to expand. We should be able to figure out –

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Cab’s on its way. I have to finish packing.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: I have a whole new appreciation for what you do. How hard it is to believe when everyone around you is telling you that you’re wrong.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Helps to know they’re idiots.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Do you think I’m an idiot?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You’re not objective. But you’re not an idiot. His lungs are still two weeks away from being viable.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: But big enough for a diagnosis.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: These tissue buds are new. Could indicate bronchopulmonary sequestration or diaphragmatic eventration.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: I was thinking bronchogenetic cysts or bronchial atresia.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Could be lung lesions. CCAM.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: What about –

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Move.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: I thought you started your vacation.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Somebody had to save our boss’ rotundous ass. Latest MRI of the Sloan fetus.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Small buds in the lungs could indicate –

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Thanks. Got that multiple choice all worked out. The question is, how do we pick between A, B, C, D and “none of the above.”

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Portable MRI’s in her room. We could get a current image –

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Fetal lungs are so tiny an MRI won’t give us the details we need.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: What would we do if this patient were not just a tadpole. Say it was an actual person.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: He… is a person.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Thanks for playing along. Pretend that it’s a one-pound adult. Forget the mom, forget the womb, the placenta. How would we get a better look at what’s in the lungs?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Transesophageal echo.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Can’t access his esophagus.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Higher resolution CT could give us a clearer –

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Too much radiation for a one-pound person.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You can’t just shoot everything down, Chase. You’re not me. Collaborate.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: A ventilation perfusion scan would be next.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: How do we get a fetus to breathe in a radioactive isotope? Idiot.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: If it were really a person and we had no other options, we’d do an exploratory surgery. Cut into his chest and have a look around.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Let’s do that. You’re the one who insists we treat it like a person. I’ll put it back when I’m done.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Me again. Your friendly neighborhood belly-squirter. We’re going to do open fetal surgery. Open the uterus cut out the fetus so we can look around. I know you can’t talk so I need you to look petrified if you consent.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: The umbilical cord won’t be cut. During surgery your body will basically serve as the baby’s heart-lung machine. We find what’s wrong and we fix it. If we can.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Don’t lower expectations if you want them to do something.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: She should know what she’s facing. This is incredibly dangerous. It risks both your lives. The only reason why we’re suggesting it is because there’s nothing else we can do.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You all here for the fetal surgery? Because we are way over capacity.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Mind each other’s personal space. There are sharp implements in the room. Like this one. Uterus is fully exposed.

utterance.speaker: Surgeon
utterance.content: And we’re in. Start draining the amniotic fluid.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Have you never sucked beer out of the bottom of a keg? Where’d you go to college? Gimme that.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Affix the pulse ox to the palm. House.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Sorry. I just realized I forgot to TiVo “Alien.”

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Fetal heart rate good, stats are stable.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Position him for the incision.

utterance.speaker: Surgeon
utterance.content: All right, I see three well-defined lesions. It’s definitely CCAM. I should be able to resect them.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It’s the mom. She’s in V-fib.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Charging. Clear.

utterance.speaker: Surgeon
utterance.content: I’m clear.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Looks like asystole. Paddling’s not going to do anything.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: It’s fine V-fib. I’m going again.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: We’re going to lose them both. Clamp! The surgery’s not doing this to her, the fetus is.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Step away, House. I’m going again.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: The only way to save her is to cut away the anchor holding her down.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: You keep going, you’re going to get electrocuted. Going again. Clear.

utterance.speaker: Surgeon
utterance.content: Heart rate’s returning to normal.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Continue with the lobectomy.

utterance.speaker: Emma
utterance.content: So my kidney, liver and lungs are all fine, just like that?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Just like that.

utterance.speaker: Emma
utterance.content: That’s amazing.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: What’s amazing is how blond your baby’s hair is.

utterance.speaker: Emma
utterance.content: My baby?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You know, the thing in your belly that tried to kill you.

utterance.speaker: Emma
utterance.content: You’ve never called him a baby before.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Any pain?

utterance.speaker: Emma
utterance.content: Nothing I can’t deal with.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You can only get out of bed to pee, poo or shower. And absolutely no sex. So stop flirting with me.

utterance.speaker: Emma
utterance.content: Sorry. So this really worked. He’ll be… normal?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Um. If you call being born twice, normal.

utterance.speaker: Emma
utterance.content: Hey, thank you.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Don’t thank me. I would have killed the kid.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Wanna grab a bite?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: In a minute. Emma asked me to bring up her camera.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: I’ll walk with you.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: When’d she take this picture of you? You look so…

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: I’m smiling. I have a nice smile.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: No. I’ve never seen you like this. She got you to… glow. What were you doing? What’d she say to you?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: I always glow.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: House. Need you to take a look at something.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I’m off the clock.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Just open it.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: First class ticket to Vancouver Island.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Shoot. It’s the wrong envelope. I think it’s great.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yeah. Who doesn’t like Canadians?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: It’s big. You’re – you’re trying to have a life. You’re trying to enjoy yourself.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You didn’t need to apologize.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: I’m not. I told you why I’m –

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You screwed up.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: I saved a life. I saved two lives.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You let your maternal instinct get the best of you and nearly killed two people. In a case like this you terminate and mom lives 10 times out of ten. You do what you did, mom and baby both die 9.9 times out of 10.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Sometimes point 1 is bigger than 9.9.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No. It’s smaller. Exactly 9.8 smaller. Always is, always will be.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Well, not for Emma. And not for her son. Now go away. And be happy.
